metadata.case_name: Appellant Company v. Kundlik Tulsiram Bhosle

facts.text: Kundlik Tulsiram Bhosle engaged as temporary Motor driver on December 22, 1954; letter stated services liable to termination at any time without notice or compensation until confirmed.
Charge sheet served on Kundlik on November 9 for allowing Conductor Vyankati to carry five passengers without tickets and unauthorized driver Sheikh Akbar to drive the bus on November 14.
Enquiry held by Depot Manager; charges found established; evidence included statements of Kundlik (signed), Conductor Surewar, Conductor Vyankati (signed).
Dismissed from service by order dated December 19, 1955, effective December 20, 1955.
Kundlik applied under s.16 C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947 to Labour Commissioner alleging no enquiry and illegal dismissal, praying for reinstatement.
Management pleaded enquiry was properly held and dismissal legal.
Assistant Labour Commissioner doubted enquiry but on evidence held charge of carrying passengers without tickets proved, unauthorized driver not (as licensed); dismissed application.
Industrial Court held Labour Commissioner lacked jurisdiction to hold enquiry, no enquiry by management; set aside order, directed reinstatement with back wages.
Appellant filed writ petition under Arts. 226/227 before Bombay High Court at Nagpur to quash Industrial Court order; dismissed on October 17, 1959.

legal_issues.text: Whether enquiry was necessary before dismissal given terms of employment.
Whether Labour Commissioner had jurisdiction to hold enquiry himself if management did not.
Whether finding of no enquiry by management was perverse.
Whether dismissal without enquiry contravened s.31 and Schedule 2 of C.P. Berar Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: No necessity to hold enquiry before dismissal due to terms of employment allowing termination without notice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Terms of contract; ordinary law of contract

petitioner_arguments.text: Labour Commissioner had jurisdiction to hold enquiry himself.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.16 C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947

petitioner_arguments.text: Finding that no enquiry held was perverse; evidence produced including signed statements.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Evidence before Labour Commissioner; perversity warrants interference under Arts. 226/227

respondent_arguments.text: No enquiry held by management; signature obtained on blank paper.
Even if enquiry held, no opportunity to cross-examine or adduce evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Dismissal without enquiry not 'in accordance with law' under Schedule 2; includes industrial law evolved by courts requiring fair enquiry.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Industrial adjudication sets aside dismissals without proper enquiry even if contract allows.

court_reasoning.text: Labour Commissioner may have jurisdiction to hold enquiry, but unnecessary to decide.
Finding of no enquiry perverse; evidence of signed statements by employee and witness; implausible forgery; omission of enquirer signature not fatal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reasonable person could reach that conclusion; error apparent on face of record.

court_reasoning.text: Industrial Court bound by perverse finding erroneously; High Court should have corrected under Arts. 226/227.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Employee never alleged improper enquiry, only no enquiry.

holdings.text: Enquiry was held; Labour Commissioner's finding perverse and error of law.
High Court erred in not interfering; writ should issue to quash Industrial Court order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Prov. Transp. Services v. Assist. Lab. Commr.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held 'law' in Schedule 2 excludes industrial law; court disagrees.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maroti v. Member, State Industrial Court
precedents_cited.relevance: Held 'law' in Schedule 2 excludes industrial law; court disagrees.

statutes_cited.name: C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Jurisdiction for dismissal disputes; dismissal must be in accordance with law or standing orders.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court jurisdiction to quash orders on writ petition.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; writ petition allowed; Industrial Court order quashed; Assistant Labour Commissioner order dismissing employee's application restored.

key_quotes.text: "The conclusion of the Assistant Labour Commissioner that there are sufficient ground to doubt whether an enquiry was really made must therefore be held to be perverse."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "when it appears to an appellate court that no person properly instructed in law and acting judicially could have reached the particular decision the Court may proceed on the assumption that mis-conception of law has been responsible for the wrong decision."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "industrial adjudication would set aside the order of dismissal and direct reinstatement of the workman where dismissal was made without proper and fair enquiry by the management"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets 'in accordance with law' to include industrial law.
